dialog.text: Why do I keep blaming others when I still feel stuck inside?
dialog.instructions: teenage, vulnerable, quick inhale, curious — slightly rushed

dialog.text: Because blame feels like armor; it keeps you from looking at the wound underneath.
dialog.instructions: calm, wise, low-register, slow pacing, soft echo — comforting authority

dialog.text: But when I blame them, at least I don't have to feel the shame or the smallness.
dialog.instructions: defensive, honest, tight throat, faster cadence

dialog.text: The shadow learned to point outward so the heart wouldn't have to open. Blame is a clever diversion.
dialog.instructions: gentle, steady, compassionate — a guiding hand

dialog.text: How do I stop? I've apologized, argued, even walked away — nothing changes.
Stopping behavior isn't healing the story. The inner work asks you to look where you've been avoiding: what pain are you protecting by blaming?
Admitting it hurts — that I felt invisible — makes me ashamed. So I lash out instead.
Name that feeling. Let it surface. Don't fix it; witness it. When you feel the ache without escaping, blame loses its grip.
I sat with it once and it flooded me — I thought I'd drown.
The breath is your lifeline. Breathe through the flood. Then say to that protective part: 'Thank you for keeping me safe. I will hold this pain now.' Choice rewires the impulse to blame.
I tried it — named it, breathed, thanked. I felt lighter, but what about the people who really hurt me?
You can forgive without excusing. Forgiveness frees you first; it doesn't erase the lesson or dismiss boundaries. Responsibility and compassion can coexist.
So letting go of blame isn't letting them off the hook — it's taking my power back.
Yes. The hero's journey is inward. Tear off the veils and choose freedom over being right. Each release of blame returns a piece of your true Self.
dialog.instructions: resonant, inspiring, slightly triumphant — slow finish

dialog.text: I'll practice: name it, breathe, thank the protector, and choose differently.
Begin now. Notice one blame in you today, meet it with curiosity, and share what you discover. Comment below — what did letting go reveal to you?
dialog.instructions: inviting, warm call to action, gentle uplift
